form.text: The definition of strong non-manipulability appeals to a topo-
logical notion of ‘large’ set of distribution as a co-meager set. The goal of the definition is
to capture the idea that, regardless of the strategy he uses to creates forecasts, the unin-
formed expert will fail on a large set of stochastic processes. This definition has been used in
the expert testing literature, but we recognize that such topological notion has well-known
drawbacks. In particular, it does not indicate odds of discrediting the uninformed expert.
We view the main contribution of our theorem to be the very fact that there exists a test
which is not manipulable. The strong non-manipulability property is a bonus.
